tn.ref: on the other side of the Jordan River from the city
tn.text: The Israelites were camped on the east side of the Jordan River. Jericho was on the west side of the river.
Balak was king of Moab. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Zippor is the father of Balak. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: Moab was very afraid of the people ... Moab was in terror of the people of Israel
tn.text: These two phrases mean the same thing, and emphasize how afraid Moab was. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Here "Moab" refers to the people of Moab. AT: "All of the Moabites were very afraid" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"because there were many of them"

tn.ref: The king of Moab said to the elders of Midian
tn.text: The Moabites and the Midianites were two different groups of people, but the Midianites were living in the land of Moab at that time.

tn.ref: This multitude will eat up all that is around us as an ox eats up the grass in a field
tn.text: The way the Israelites will destroy their enemies is spoken of as if they were an ox eating up the grass in a field. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])

tn.ref: Now Balak son of Zippor was king of Moab at that time
tn.text: This changes from the main story to background information about Balak. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"Balak sent messengers"
This is the name of Balaam's father. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of a city. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: of his nation and his people
tn.text: "of Balaam's nation and people"
"Balak called Balaam." Balak did not speak to Balaam directly, but did so through the messengers he sent.

tn.ref: They cover the face of the earth
tn.text: This is an exaggeration to emphasize how numerous they were. AT: "They are extremely numerous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This refers to the surface of the earth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"chase them"

tn.ref: I know that whomever you bless will be blessed, and whomever you curse will be cursed
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "I know you have the power to bless or to curse people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The abstract noun "divination" can be stated as an action. AT: "money to pay Balaam to curse Israel" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
You may prefer to say "They went to Balaam" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
Here "words" refers to the message. AT: "told him the message from Balak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This is the name of a man. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:num:22:02|22:2]].
Balaam's report is spoken of as if it were something that he would carry to the messengers. AT: "I will tell you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"God appeared to Balaam"

tn.ref: Who are these men who came to you?
tn.text: Yahweh uses a question to introduce a new topic of conversation. This rhetorical question can be translated as a statement. AT: "Tell me about these men who came to you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
These are the names of men. See how you translated these in [[:en:bible:notes:num:22:02|22:2]].

tn.ref: Look, the people ... drive them out
tn.text: Balaam restates the message that Balak sent to him. See how you translated many of these phrases in [[:en:bible:notes:num:22:05|22:5-6]].
"chase them away"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "because I have blessed them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is the name of a man. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:num:22:02|22:2]].
You may prefer to say "They went to Balaam" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
This is the name of a man. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:num:22:02|22:2]].
The singular noun refers to the Israelites as a group. AT: "this group of people"
This is the name of a man. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:num:22:02|22:2]].

tn.ref: Even if Balak would give me his palace full of silver and gold
tn.text: Balaam is describing something that would never happen. He is emphasizing that there is nothing that could make him disobey Yahweh. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: I cannot go beyond the word of Yahweh ... and do less or more than what he tells me
tn.text: This means Balaam cannot disobey Yahweh in any way.
A saddle is a seat put on the back of an animal in order to ride it.

The increase in God's anger is spoken of as if it was a fire starting to burn. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God became very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"as an enemy to Balaam" or "in order to stop Balaam"
A sword is drawn from its sheath in order to be ready to use. AT: "with his sword ready to attack" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: The donkey turned off the road and went into a field
tn.text: The donkey did this to avoid the angel of Yahweh.
Sometimes animals are referred to as "her" or "she." AT: "to turn it back"
This was an attempt to escape from the angel of Yahweh in the road.
Sometimes animals are referred to as "her" or "she." AT: "It went"
"pushed Balaam's foot against it" or "hurt Balaam's foot against it"

The increase in Balaam's anger is spoken of as if it was a fire starting to burn. This can be stated in active form. See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:num:22:21|22:22]]. AT: "Balaam became very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Then Yahweh opened the donkey's mouth so she could talk
tn.text: Opening the mouth is associated with the ability to speak. AT: "Then Yahweh gave the donkey the ability to speak like a human would speak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"The donkey said to Balaam"

tn.ref: Am not I your donkey on which you have ridden all your life long to this present day?
tn.text: This rhetorical question was used to convict Balaam that his judgment of the donkey was unfair. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "I am your donkey on which you have ridden all your life, right up to the present moment." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Have I ever been in the habit of doing such things to you before?
tn.text: This rhetorical question was used to further convict Balaam that his judgment of the donkey was unfair. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "I have never been in the habit of doing such things to you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Then Yahweh opened Balaam's eyes, and he saw the angel of Yahweh
tn.text: To "open one's eyes" is associated with being able to see. AT: "Then Yahweh gave Balaam the ability to see the angel of Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

A sword is drawn from its sheath in order to be ready to use. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:num:22:21|22:23]]. AT: "with his sword ready to attack" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: Balaam lowered his head and lay facedown
tn.text: This indicates that Balaam is humbling himself before the angel. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])

tn.ref: Why have you struck your donkey these three times?
tn.text: This rhetorical question is used to accuse Balaam of doing wrong. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should not have struck your donkey these three times." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"as an enemy to you" or "to oppose you"

tn.ref: If she had not turned ... killed you and spared her life
tn.text: This hypothetical statement indicated what could have happened, but it did not because the donkey's actions saved Balaam. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])

tn.ref: So now, if it is displeasing to you
tn.text: "So if you do not want me to continue going" (UDB)
"with the leaders whom Balak had sent." See how you translated "Balak" in [[:en:bible:notes:num:22:02|22:2]].
This is the name of a river. See how you translated it in [[:en:bible:notes:num:21:12|21:13]].

tn.ref: Did I not send men to you to summon you?
tn.text: This rhetorical question is used to rebuke Balaam for delaying to come. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "Surely I sent men to summon you." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Why did you not come to me?
tn.text: This rhetorical question is used to rebuke Balaam for delaying to come. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "You should have come to me!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Am I not able to honor you?
tn.text: This rhetorical question is used to rebuke Balaam for delaying to come. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "Surely you know that I am able to pay you money for coming to me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Do I now have any power to say anything?
tn.text: Balaam uses this rhetorical question to tell Balak that he will not be able to do everything that Balak asks him to do. This can be translated as a statement. AT: "But I have no power to say anything I want" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]]).

tn.ref: the words that God puts into my mouth
tn.text: Here "words" refers to the message from God. The message is spoken of as if it is something that God put into his mouth. AT: "the message that God wants me to say" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This is the name of a town. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"some of the meat from the sacrifices"

Possible meanings are 1) this refers to the same place as Bamoth in [[:en:bible:notes:num:21:19|21:19]]. The word Bamoth means "the high place," or 2) this is another high place where people sacrificed to Baal.
